results.title: Work can be measured: a work measurement study on a power loaded face
results.creator_credit: Kitty Marshall, National Coal Board and Ralph Elton
results.brief_description: Deals with the application of the technique of work study methods in the mine. A study is made of the work on a power-loaded coalface by breaking down the work into elements, assessing the speed of the workers, taking into account the degrees of monotony, and calculating manning economies.

results.title: Work around the clock
results.creator_credit: Ivo Burum, Helen Gaynor, Alfred Hospital and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Nurses”.
Nurses “was filmed by four nurses and their friends at the Alfred Hospital in Melbourne to capture the real life drama of nursing from a very different perspective…their own” Nurses are: Kerryn O’Rourke - Oncology. Trish Builic - Psychiatric (to the homeless). Jane Newham - Emergency. Cassie Steward - Theatre. Ep 2: Opens with wonderfully honest scene about the difficulties of getting up in the morning, and the way the twenty-four hour, year round demands of nursing that throw your body and personal life out. Jane, who has been in a relationship for five months talks about the cycle of crankiness that comes whenever she works nights. And the difficulties of getting a partner, used to a nine to five work day, to understand. Trish, who has just been proposed to (lots of drama) says upfront that she chose to specialise in psychiatric because she didn’t think she could work nights relentlessly, and even so she still carries responsibility beyond working hours. Kerryn takes the audience through a night shift and we see that its the little things that get you through, brushing your teeth, coming home to clean bed sheets. And in theatre there are some gory scenes, before Cassie takes us out the back for a cigarette…

results.title: Work and play (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Can You Avoid Cancer?”.
What are the risks of getting cancer from substances you breathe in or handle at work? Or from air pollution? Or from sitting in the sun? This program looks at the links between cancer and industry, and suggests some steps for preventing even more cancer deaths in the future

results.title: Work [SILENT]
results.creator_credit: Jessie T Robbins, Essanay Film Manufacturing Company and Charles Chaplin
results.brief_description: Work, Charlie Chaplin’s eighth film for Essanay casts Charlie as a wallpaper-hanger’s assistant who must pull the wagon containing the boss (Charles Insley) and all his gear through the city streets and up some imposing hills (created by using tilted camera angles). Charlie is little more than a beast of burden and must do all the work when they arrive at a wealthy couple’s (Billy Armstrong and Marta Golden) home. The woman of the house suspects the workers of being dishonest when she catches Charlie admiring a small statue, and she locks up her valuables in a safe. This prompts Charlie to “lock up” his and his boss’s watches and cash by pinning them into his pants pocket. Charlie proves to be an inept decorator, making a huge mess and causing his boss to get a bucket of wallpaper paste over his head. He befriends Edna Purviance, the maid, and in a rather intimate scene, tells her his story and hopes for the future. The wife’s lover, Leo White arrives, but when he sees that the husband is still home, he pretends to be a workman. The husband is wise to the deal and attacks his wife’s lover, eventually pulling out a revolver and chasing him around the house. A stray bullet hits the gas stove which explodes. In the famous last scene, Charlie emerges from the inverted oven door, exhales some smoke, and, sizing up the situation, smiles into the camera.

results.title: Work
results.creator_credit: Maija Rove and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Dragon’s tongue”.
Colin McKerras introduces this lesson, which centres on work. He introduces vocabulary associated with work, such as “How many days a week do you work?” and “What do you want to do when you leave school?” We see workers in a factory in Beijing and talk to school students about their future plans. The calligraphy section shows the character “to produce” and associated characters for “production”, “products” and “maternity leave” The two dramatised sections “Work or study” which depicts a Chinese family in Australia, and “Work experience” showing a student on work experience assignments, include much of the vocabulary introduced. In Mandarin and English.

results.title: Work
results.creator_credit: Rachel Reichman, Susan A Stover and Tina Kacandes
results.brief_description: Slow-paced and thoughtful, “Work” tells the story of two young women living in a depressed factory town in the heartland of America, whose paths are drawn together in an unexpected way. Jenny (Cynthia Kaplan) is married to Will who works in the mill and wants to try and save his job by siding with both management and the workers, but ends up by finding himself on the outer anyway. Jenny is unemployed but makes half-hearted attempts in applying for work, most times being put down or humiliated for her lack of skills or experience. Bored and restless, Jenny finds satisfaction in the company of June (Sonja Sohn), her next door African American neighbour who is an athlete and up and coming college student. Jenny and June’s relationship blossoms into an affair of secret conversations and erotic encounters, providing a release for Jenny’s sense of futility and hopelessness and allowing her to explore her sexuality. However, in the end Jenny has no control over the direction her life will take - choices are made, and so be it. Reichman has given this film a cinema verite style and through her direction, the film has retained an essential quality of realism and truism. Cinematography by Steven Giuliano. Cast also includes Peter Sprague, Steven Garfield, Deirdre Lewis, Patt Franklin.

results.title: Words for battle
results.brief_description: A documentary which sets to film great passages of prose and poetry relevant to the struggle of World War II. Spoken by Sir Laurence Olivier, the quotations are taken from the writings of Camden, Milton, William Blake, Robert Browning, Abraham Lincoln, Rudyard Kipling and Winston Churchill.

results.title: Words are not enough
results.creator_credit: Leon Clore, Basic Films and Fred Moore
results.brief_description: Problems of communication arise at all levels of human relationship, including management and workers. Communication structures become more complex as the distance between boardroom and shop floor increase, and as specialists and functional managers authority become confused with line management. Stimulates constructive thought and discussion rather than suggests techniques.
